This week's best reads from the front lines of the fight for civil liberties.
 
A FORUM FOR REPARATIONS

Racial Justice in America Depends on Understanding the Truth of Our Past

It's time we start having honest, direct conversations about reparations. August will mark the 400th anniversary of the first enslaved people being sold into bondage in America and it's time we confront this history and its legacy. In January, Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee re-introduced H.R. 40, a bill to establish a commission to study reparations. In this historic moment, the ACLU has provided a forum for Black thinkers and activists to write about why reparations are necessary justice for America's original sin. These articles and essays are intended to serve as the beginning of a critical conversation. Read more →

By Jeffery Robinson, Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, Nkechi Taifa, Julianne Malveaux, V.P. Franklin, Aislinn Pulley, Hilary Beckles, and Iva E. Carruthers
June 17, 2019

 
AT LIBERTY PODCAST

The Next Frontier in Data Privacy

This week marks the one-year anniversary of arguably the most important privacy ruling of the digital age. In Carpenter v. the United States, the Supreme Court ruled that police violated the Fourth Amendment when they secured months' worth of a robbery suspect's location information from his cell phone company without a warrant. Nathan Freed Wessler, the ACLU attorney who argued and won the case, discusses Carpenter's legacy and where the battle for digital privacy is headed next. Listen here →

By ACLU Staff
June 20, 2019
 
A THREAT REEMERGES

Homan's Appointment as Trump 'Border Czar' Will Continue the Administration's Cruel Border Policies

Last week, Trump announced that Thomas Homan, the former director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement who signed the administration's family separation memo, will return to the administration as "border czar." This appointment will intensify the administration's inhuman border policies. We are calling on Congress to continue to use its oversight power to hold Homan accountable for the abuse that he has already perpetrated and to oppose the danger he represents for vulnerable immigrant populations. Read more →

By Brian Tashman
June 14, 2019
 
TEAR IT DOWN

The Immigration System Is Inhumane. The Next President Must Dismantle It.

The next president should overhaul the immigration system by establishing a path to citizenship, ending ICE detainers, and reducing the size of the immigration prison system by 75 percent. Although the Trump administration has escalated its immigration enforcement, its policies are part of longstanding practices begun by Democrats and Republicans decades before Trump came to office. Presidential candidates need to show how they will improve the immigration system with policy specifics. Read more →

By Ruthie Epstein
June 17, 2019
 
HISTORY REMAINS THE REALITY

Black Boys Aren't 'Wolf Packs' and Abusive Prosecutors Aren't 'Lone Wolves'

Ava DuVernay's "When They See Us" tells the story of five Black and Latinx boys who were wrongly imprisoned over 30 years ago, but it reminds us that the justice system still harbors the same prejudices today. The individual conduct of the prosecutors, police, and media in this story is a manifestation of a larger system that is built to oppress, control, and dehumanize people of color. Across the country, there are movements at local, state and national levels calling for accountability and exploring alternatives to the current system of policing, and they must be heard for true reform to occur. Read more →

By Somil Trivedi and Nusrat Choudhury
June 18, 2019
 
A FIREWALL FOR REPRODUCTIVE FREEDOM

After Some States Pass Abortion Bans, Other States Pass New Protections

A number of states – including Illinois, Vermont, and Maine – have passed historic bills protecting the fundamental right to reproductive health care. These bills are the result of activists’ efforts and state lawmakers responding to attacks on abortion rights in states in the South and Midwest. We must continue to expand state protections for reproductive rights because the ability to exercise these rights should not depend on where you live. Read more →

By Jessica Arons
June 18, 2019
 
FAILING THE CONSTITUTION

Supreme Court Undermines Religious Neutrality in Permitting Giant Governmental Cross

This week, the Supreme Court ruled that the government display of a 40-foot cross as a memorial to veterans does not violate the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. Although this ruling was limited, it demonstrates a failure on the part of the court to protect the separation of church and state. The justices in the majority misconstrued the circumstances surrounding the cross to undermine a critical constitutional principle. Read more →

By Daniel Mach and Heather L. Weaver
June 20, 2019
